On Oct 2, 2009, at 3:40 PM, Bill Burke wrote:

> Yeah, somebody will have to explain to me why (or if) the Reservation
> example I gave breaks the stateless constraint of REST.  Where I think

Well - under the disguise of a "transaction", the server is  
maintaining per-client state. In stead of answering your question  
directly, let me ask you whether have you examined the scalability  
characteristics of your proposed design.

It may be worthwhile to start from basics, apply each constraint one  
by one, and whether your approach benefits. The discussion around the  
kind of resources needed, media types, link rels, link headers vs link  
elements in some XML format are implementation details. So far, this  
post does not make a case of why an transactional application should  
be built the way you propose.

Here is a minor point. There is no such thing as a "sub-resource".  
That term may be part of the mental model of some developers, but it  
has no consequence to the protocol.

Subbu
